div.p:
svasti śrimaN vijayāditya-satyāśraya-śri-prithivi-bhallabha-mahārā
ja-Athirāja-paramēśvara-bhaṭāraḷa vijayarājya-saṁvatsaraṁbu
prathama-rēājyaṁbuna rēṇḍ-agun ēṇḍu vaṇarājuL vaṁgaru
viṣayaṁbu Ēḷa varipaḷa caḷki ḷēnṟurājula niṭuru paṭu
gana Ēḷucu gamuṇḍalli gōtraṁbuna vēḷāla guṇḍiya pāṟa veneyaṟēgari
racamānaṁbuna Ēbhadi maṟuntuṟlu Iccinadi dēni
ki sāpidhōṇaya bōḷu kundābākaḷu vēdaribōḷu valaya
ṟunēduṁbālu paṭṭigā puḷūjanapaṟu Ajja va pāṟu
vara ? mavaṟuṭaccamuḷu dēniki vakraṁbu vaccuvāru pañca
mahāpātakasaṁyuktul aguḷca

app.note: The scribe omitted one akṣara in the word saṁvatsaraṁbu of the same line, and he might therefore simply have forgotten two akṣaras in this word. There might be a chance, however, that it is sort of an abbreviated way of writing the biruda. The editors state in a footnote that saṁya has to be read satyāśraya.

In many cases the ansuvāra is written on top of the akṣara it is supposed to be pronounced before instead of after in Telugu inscriptions. It is noteworthy, that the first anusvāra is written on top of the ⟨sa⟩ and the second on top of the ⟨bu⟩ in this word; but the second akṣara has to be read ⟨ṁbu⟩. The same occurs with ⟨ṁbu⟩ in line six. The editors state in a footnote that the word has to be read saṁvatsaraṁbu.

The anusvāra is written on top of the ⟨ga⟩ as is often the case in Telugu inscriptions; the reading vaṁga is furthermore secured by other inscriptions (see 33456 B3). The editors state in a footnote that the word has to be read as vaṁganūru. Regarding the slip of the pen in line 2 and line 1 (if it is not an abbreviation) a further slip at this spot is possible as well.

div.p:
The scribe did not differentiate between long ⟨ī⟩ and short ⟨i⟩. Since this could reflect an actual indifference towards distinguishing vowel length in pronunctiation in this respect, the text was not "normalized". In the scribe's ductus the akṣaras ⟨da⟩ and ⟨ṭa⟩ look alike. He further does not differentiate between ⟨dha⟩ and ⟨tha⟩ both of which are written with a dot in the middle. A viṣaya or nāṇḍu with the name vaṁganūr is mentioned (and written clearly) in 142 and also mentioned in 6042. The place name consists of the elements vaṁgan(V) and ūru "village"; the first element could go back to Telugu vaṁka "crooked", compare Kannaḍa vaṁka "the winding course of a stream" (1370), with locative suffix. Hence, the place name could mean "village at the river curve". The modern village Vaṁganūr actually is situated at a curve of the Pennar river. It might hence be possible that the viṣaya was also simply called vaṁgana "at the river curve" (56 B3) if it wasn't really vaṁganūr. The attested vaṁgaru on the other hand (56 C3) very probably is a misspelling for vaṁganūru because of etymological reasons.
The inscription stops after the first third of line 11 although the imprecation verse is not completed and plenty of space is still left. It is possible that the inscription originally continued in the next line but regarding the flaws that the scribe seems to be responsible for it is also possible that he simply forgot to complete his task.
The inscription was noted in A. R. No. B 10 of 1959-1960 and first published by K. V. Ramesh and S. S. Ramachandra Murthy with annotations and a picture (334-33556 C).
